translations.en: It was most widely applied on porcelains in the Song Dynasty, producing distinctive effects in ceramics made at the Yue, Ding, Cizhou, Yaozhou, Longquan, and Jingdezhen kilns.

translations.zh: 其中耀州窑刻花青瓷受到的评价最高，纹饰下刀较深，刀锋犀利洒脱，具有浅浮雕般立体感，被推为宋代各窑瓷器刻花之冠。
translations.en: The finest examples were celadon made at Yaozhou.

translations.zh: 装饰新颖的其他民窑陶瓷宋、金时期的民窑瓷器，装饰风格朴实、生活气息浓郁，以磁州窑和磁州窑系产品最具代表。
translations.en: Novel Decoration:Ceramics from other Private Kilns In the Song and Jin dynasties, decoration on porcelain produced in private kilns was lively and close to daily life.

translations.zh: 磁州窑是北方著名民窑，其遗址位于今河北省磁县境内，因磁县古称磁州，故这里的瓷窑被称作“磁州窑”。
translations.en: The most representative ones were from the Cizhou kilns.

translations.zh: 磁州窑主要烧造白釉、黑釉、褐釉、白地黑（褐）花瓷和低温铅釉陶等，装饰技法常见彩绘、刻、划、剔等，手法娴熟，纹饰优美。
translations.en: Located in present-day Cixian County, Hebei Province, the Cizhou kiln was a famous private kiln in the north in the Northern Song Dynasty and Jin Dynasty.

translations.zh: 装饰题材丰富，各种动物、植物、文字、诗词、谚语和反映民俗生活的人物等，应有尽有，深受人们喜爱。
translations.en: It chiefly produced white-, black-, and brown-glazed ceramics, as well as black- or brown-painted white-glazed ceramics and tri-colour pottery wares.

translations.zh: 受磁州窑影响，宋、金、元时期河北、河南、山东、陕西、山西等地瓷窑，均曾烧造类似风格的瓷器，形成庞大的磁州窑系。
translations.en: Cizhou wares won great popularity, and inspired kilns in Hebei, Henan, Shandong, Shaanxi, and Shanxi to make similar products during the Song, Jin, and Yuan dynasties.

translations.zh: 其中较为重要的有河南登封窑、当阳峪窑、扒村窑等，山西大同窑、河津窑、长治窑等。
translations.en: An extended Cizhou kiln system was thus formed.

source.title_zh: 光致茂美的景德镇窑青白瓷
source.title_en: Glossy Bluish-white Porcelain of the Jingdezhen Kilns

translations.zh: 最迟在唐代景德镇窑已开始烧造瓷器，产品胎薄质坚、光致茂美，釉色青中闪白、白中泛青，颇似天然美玉，故被宋人比作青白玉。
translations.en: The Jingdezhen kilns began production no later than the Tang Dynasty, when celadon was the major product.

source.title_zh: 光致茂美的景德镇窑青白瓷
source.title_en: Glossy Bluish-white Porcelain of the Jingdezhen Kilns

translations.zh: 青白瓷造型丰富，除饮食用器外，还有文具、妆具、陈设器、明器、宗教造像等。
translations.en: Both celadon and white wares were manufactured during the Five Dynasties, while bluish-white porcelain wares were created and produced in the Northern Song Dynasty.

source.title_zh: 光致茂美的景德镇窑青白瓷
source.title_en: Glossy Bluish-white Porcelain of the Jingdezhen Kilns

translations.zh: 装饰技法主要有刻、划、剔、模印、镂空、雕塑等，装饰题材多见花草、鸾凤、婴戏、水波、云气等纹饰。
translations.en: Jingdezhen bluish-white porcelain was known as "bluish-white jade" in the Song Dynasty.

translations.zh: 光亮如漆的黑釉瓷宋、金时期，南北方瓷窑普遍烧造黑釉瓷器。
translations.en: Glossy Black-glazed Wares Black-glazed wares were manufactured across China in the Song and Jin dynasties.

translations.zh: 随着斗茶风俗的盛行，最适宜斗茶的黑釉茶盏风靡一时，产地主要集中在河北、河南、山西、四川、江西、福建等地。
translations.en: As tea connoisseurship was in vogue, black-glazed porcelain gained popularity as the best backdrop for assessing tea.

translations.zh: 南方以福建的建窑产品最为著名，其胎体厚重，釉色漆黑光亮，有的釉面布满由氧化铁结晶而形成的斑纹，变化万千，人们赋予其颇具文采的名称，如“曜变”“鹧鸪斑”，“兔毫”等。
translations.en: Black-glazed wares were primarily produced in Hebei, Henan, Shanxi, Sichuan, Jiangxi, and Fujian provinces, with the most renowned coming from the Jian kilns in Fujian.

translations.zh: 江西吉州窑工匠发挥聪明才智，创烧出斑釉、剪纸贴花、木叶贴花等装饰技法。
translations.en: Black-glazed wares with tortoise shell speckles, paper-cut patterns, and leaf patterns were created and produced in the Jizhou kilns, Jiangxi Province.

translations.zh: 北方瓷窑烧造的黑釉油滴斑、酱色斑、凸线纹等品种，亦颇具特色。
translations.en: Meanwhile, the kilns in the north produced black-glazed wares with oil-drop speckles, brown speckles, and raised-thread patterns.

source.title_zh: 胜似美玉的龙泉窑青瓷
source.title_en: Jade-like Celadon of the Longquan Kilns

translations.zh: 胜似美玉的龙泉窑青瓷龙泉窑是中国古代著名青瓷窑之一，其中心窑场位于今浙江省龙泉市境内。
translations.en: The Longquan kilns were clustered in present-day Longquan, Zhejiang Province.

source.title_zh: 胜似美玉的龙泉窑青瓷
source.title_en: Jade-like Celadon of the Longquan Kilns

translations.zh: 创烧于晚唐、五代，北宋开始兴盛，南宋至明初是其鼎盛时期，此后窑火不歇，至今仍在烧造。
translations.en: Established in the late Tang and Five Dynasties, the kilns began to build momentum in the Northern Song Dynasty and reached their peak in the centuries from the Southern Song to the early Ming.

source.title_zh: 胜似美玉的龙泉窑青瓷
source.title_en: Jade-like Celadon of the Longquan Kilns

translations.zh: 产品除供民间使用外，亦曾进贡宫廷，并行销海外。
translations.en: Longquan wares were popular with both domestic and overseas customers, with the celadon becoming known for its pure green colour.

source.title_zh: 胜似美玉的龙泉窑青瓷
source.title_en: Jade-like Celadon of the Longquan Kilns

translations.zh: 南宋时期，龙泉窑主要烧造釉层乳浊的石灰碱釉瓷，釉色以梅子青和粉青最负盛名，其釉层凝厚、釉面匀净，胜似天然美玉。
translations.en: The plum-green and light-green-blue celadon of the Southern Song Dynasty won particular admiration.

translations.zh: 刻花犀利洒脱的耀州窑青瓷耀州窑遗址位于今陕西省铜川市，中心窑场在黄堡镇。
translations.en: Celadon with Carved Decoration from Yaozhou Kilns Located in present-day Tongchuan, Shaanxi Province, the Yaozhou kilns were so named because Tongchuan was part of Yaozhou Prefecture in the Northern Song Dynasty.

translations.zh: 其始烧于唐代，盛于北宋至金代，延续烧造至今。
translations.en: The kilns were first established in the Tang Dynasty and thrived in the Northern Song and Jin dynasties, but firing has continued there down to the present day

translations.zh: 装饰技法主要有刻、划、印、镂空、雕塑等，尤以刻花技艺最受人称道，其手法娴熟，刀锋犀利洒脱，纹饰具有浅浮雕感，水平为宋、金烧造刻花瓷器的各窑之冠。
translations.en: The decorative techniques included carving, incising, impressing, hollow engraving, and sculpting.

translations.zh: 装饰题材非常丰富，诸如花卉、花鸟、人物等，无所不有。
translations.en: Products with carved patterns were the most outstanding, surpassing all other Song and Jin ceramics with carved designs.

translations.zh: 耀州窑除了烧造青瓷外，还兼烧酱釉、黑釉、黑釉酱色斑瓷等。
translations.en: In addition to celadon wares, the Yaozhou kilns also manufactured brown-glazed, black-glazed, and brown-speckled black-glazed wares.

translations.zh: 金代耀州窑青瓷釉色偏黄，开始出现涩圈叠烧工艺。
translations.en: Yaozhou kiln celadon of the Jin Dynasty took on a yellowish hue.

translations.zh: 此时还创烧一种高档的月白釉瓷，多为素面，釉色淡雅，釉面洁净，惹人喜爱，主要烧造于黄堡镇中心窑场。
translations.en: Also in the Jin Dynasty, up-stacked firing with an unglazed ring inside was invented.

translations.zh: 印花陶瓷装饰技法之一。
translations.en: Impressed Decoration

translations.zh: 系指用带有花纹的印戳或印模在已成型的半干坯体上印出纹饰，印戳或印模一般用胎泥制作而成。
translations.en: Impressing is a technique used in ceramic manufacturing.

translations.zh: 这一技法在西晋、隋代青瓷，宋、金时期定窑、耀州窑瓷器，以及宋、元及以后的景德镇窑瓷器上广泛使用。
translations.en: Artisans used small seals or moulds to put motifs on half-dried and unfired body of the porcelain piece.

translations.zh: 尤其是宋、金时期的定窑印花瓷器，纹饰清晰，构图严谨，堪称中国古代印花瓷器之冠。
translations.en: This technique was used in celadon making in the Western Jin and Sui dynasties, in the Ding and Yaozhou kilns during the Song and Jin dynasties, and in the Jingdezhen kilns from the Song Dynasty onwards.

translations.zh: 定窑遗址出土的金代印花模河北省曲阳县文物保管所藏
translations.en: Impressed Ding wares of the Northern Song and Jin dynasties have been acclaimed the finest of their kind, with well-structured and clear decoration

source.title_zh: 色彩绚烂的钧窑瓷器
source.title_en: Polychrome Ceramics of the Jun Kilns

translations.zh: 钧窑遗址位于今河南省禹州市区古钧台与八卦洞附近，故亦称钧台窑、八卦洞窑。
translations.en: Located near Juntai and Baguadong in present-day Yuzhou City, Henan Province, the Jun kilns were also known as the Juntai or Baguadong kilns.

source.title_zh: 色彩绚烂的钧窑瓷器
source.title_en: Polychrome Ceramics of the Jun Kilns

translations.zh: 钧窑瓷器素以釉装饰而闻名于世，主要有天蓝釉、月白釉、天蓝釉加紫红斑、窑变釉等。
translations.en: Jun ware was famous all over the country for its azure glaze, pale blue glaze, copper-red speckles in azure glaze, and transmutation glaze.

source.title_zh: 色彩绚烂的钧窑瓷器
source.title_en: Polychrome Ceramics of the Jun Kilns

translations.zh: 钧窑瓷器可分为陈设和日用两大类，即所谓“官钧”和“民钧”。
translations.en: 'Jun wares for official use' are mainly zun-shaped beakers with vertical flanges, flowerpots, and flowerpot salvers.

source.title_zh: 色彩绚烂的钧窑瓷器
source.title_en: Polychrome Ceramics of the Jun Kilns

translations.zh: 对于“官钧”瓷器的年代，学术界也有人认为不是北宋，而是元代末年至明代初年。
translations.en: Some scholars date them to the late Yuan and early Ming dynasties, rather than the Northern Song Dynasty.

source.title_zh: 色彩绚烂的钧窑瓷器
source.title_en: Polychrome Ceramics of the Jun Kilns

translations.zh: “民钧”瓷器造型主要有盘、碗、杯、盏托、洗、瓶、罐等，一般以天蓝釉或天蓝釉紫红斑装饰。
translations.en: 'Jun wares for daily use' chiefly include plates, bowls, cups, saucers, brush washers, vases, and jars, and are generally coated with either a pure azure glaze or an azure glaze with grey-purple speckles.

translations.zh: 洁白恬静的定窑白瓷定窑遗址位于今河北省曲阳县，因曲阳县在北宋隶属定州，故这里的瓷窑被称作“定窑”。
translations.en: Pure White Porcelain of the Ding Kilns Located in present-day Quyang County, Hebei Province, the Ding kilns were named after Dingzhou Prefecture, the area's administrative name in the Northern Song Dynasty.

translations.zh: 始烧于唐代，兴烧造白瓷而闻名于世，兼烧黑釉、酱釉、绿釉瓷，分别被称作“黑定”盛于北宋、金代。
translations.en: The Ding kilns began to produce white porcelain in the Tang Dynasty and thrived during the Northern Song and Jin dynasties.

translations.zh: 北宋时期，定窑曾进行工艺改革，大量采用“覆烧”工艺，产量激增。
translations.en: In the Northern Song Dynasty, the technique of upside-down firing enabled a sharp increase in production.

translations.zh: 产品除光素者外，还常以印、刻、剔、划、描金等技法进行装饰。
translations.en: In addition to plain designs, the products were also decorated with impressed, carved, cut-glaze, incised, and gold-painted decoration.

translations.zh: 尤以印花装饰最具特色，构图严谨，图案清晰，题材广泛，“五王水平居宋、金各窑瓷器印花装饰之首。
translations.en: Among these, products with impressed floral decoration were the most outstanding and surpassed all other impressed Song and Jin ceramics.

translations.zh: “巧用缺陷”白的哥窑瓷器这里所说的哥窑系指传世哥窑，其遗址至今尚未被发现，学术界有诸多说法，目前比较一致的看法是哥窑遗址有可能在杭州凤凰山麓。
translations.en: Making a Virtue of Imperfection: Porcelain of the Ge Kilns All known Ge kiln wares have been passed down, rather than excavated, as the kiln site is yet to be located.

translations.zh: 从现主要收藏在故宫博物院和台北故宫博物院的原清代宫廷旧藏哥窑瓷器看，其造型主要有盘、碗、杯、洗、瓶、壶、炉、罐等。
translations.en: However, it is widely agreed that the site is likely to be at the foot of Phoenix Hill in Hangzhou.

translations.zh: 器物胎体多呈灰黑色，釉面润泽如酥，釉色有青灰、米黄等。
translations.en: Ge kiln wares in the Qing court collection generally feature a grey-black body with a green-grey or puffed-rice yellow glaze.

translations.zh: 釉层较厚，釉面一般开有大小两种片纹，大片纹呈灰黑色、小片纹呈黄褐色，俗称“金丝铁线”。
translations.en: The glaze coating was usually covered with crackles forming panes of different sizes, with large panes featuring grey-black crackles and small panes formed by yellow-brown ones.

translations.zh: 片纹系因釉的膨胀系数大于胎的膨胀系数所致，本属于制瓷工艺缺陷之一，但却被陶工巧妙利用，控制在一定范围内，形成错落有致、别具一格的纹片釉装饰。
translations.en: These have become known as"gold threads and iron lines".

translations.zh: 淡雅含蓄的汝窑青瓷
translations.en: Elegant Celadon of the Ru Kilns

translations.zh: 因宝丰县在北宋时期归汝州管辖，故设在这里的瓷窑被称作“汝窑”。
translations.en: The term "Ru kilns" refers to the kilns in the reign of Emperor Huizong of the Northern Song Dynasty.

translations.zh: 汝窑为宫廷烧造的青瓷极为讲究，胎呈香灰色，釉呈淡天青色，釉面多开有细碎的片纹，俗称“冰裂纹”。
translations.en: Located at present-day Qingliangsi Village, Daying Town, Baofeng County, Henan Province, the Ru kilns were established to manufacture celadon wares exclusively for the Song Court.

translations.zh: 器物造型规整，见有碗、盏、钵、洗、盘、碟、茶盏托、酒盏托、尊、瓶、樽式炉、子、出香等。
translations.en: Ru-kiln celadon features an ash-grey body with a light azure glaze coating.

translations.zh: 因多采用“裹足支烧”，致使器物外底多留有细小的支钉痕，俗称“芝麻挣钉”。
translations.en: The coating characteristically has tiny marks commonly known as "sesame marks".

translations.zh: 汝窑青瓷历来被推崇为中国古代文人审美的典范，堪称宋代瓷器艺术之冠。
translations.en: Ru-kiln celadon wares have been admired as the finest Song porcelain and seen as the epitome of China's historical literati aesthetics.

source.title_zh: 名窑送出辽、宋、西夏、金陶瓷（公元907～1279年）
source.title_en: Kilns Famous Ceramics of the Liao, Song, Western Xia and Jin Dynasties

translations.zh: 辽、宋、西夏、金时期，陶瓷业蓬勃发展，名窑遍布各地，出现了陶瓷史上前所未有的兴盛局面。
translations.en: The ceramic industry flourished in the Liao, Song, Western Xia, and Jin dynasties, with renowned kilns across the land.

source.title_zh: 名窑送出辽、宋、西夏、金陶瓷（公元907～1279年）
source.title_en: Kilns Famous Ceramics of the Liao, Song, Western Xia and Jin Dynasties

translations.zh: 在民窑获得发展的基础上，朝廷还在南北方相继设窑专门烧造宫廷用瓷。
translations.en: Building on the development of private kilns, the court established official kilns (guan yao) to make ceramics exclusively for imperial use.

source.title_zh: 名窑送出辽、宋、西夏、金陶瓷（公元907～1279年）
source.title_en: Kilns Famous Ceramics of the Liao, Song, Western Xia and Jin Dynasties

translations.zh: 汝窑、官窑、哥窑、定窑、钧窑、耀州窑、磁州窑、越窑、龙泉窑、景德镇窑、吉州窑、建窑等名窑烧造的瓷器，备受后人推崇。
translations.en: Ceramics from the Ru, Guan, Ge, Ding, Jun, Yaozhou, Cizhou, Yue, Longquan, Jingdezhen, Jizhou, and Jian kilns won great admiration from later generations.

source.title_zh: 名窑送出辽、宋、西夏、金陶瓷（公元907～1279年）
source.title_en: Kilns Famous Ceramics of the Liao, Song, Western Xia and Jin Dynasties

translations.zh: 北方地区的辽、西夏陶瓷，既受中原陶瓷工艺影响，又具有民族风格，成为中国陶瓷史上民族大融合的物证之一。
translations.en: Ceramics manufactured in the Liao and Western Xia territories in the north integrated porcelain-making techniques from the Central Plains with distinctive ethnic styles.

source.title_zh: 名窑送出辽、宋、西夏、金陶瓷（公元907～1279年）
source.title_en: Kilns Famous Ceramics of the Liao, Song, Western Xia and Jin Dynasties

translations.zh: 女真人灭北宋后，金代制瓷业在北宋基础上继续发展，定窑、钧窑、耀州窑、磁州窑等著名瓷窑，均烧造出具有独特艺术风格的陶瓷。
translations.en: Porcelain-making in the Jin Dynasty (1115-1234) further developed on the basis of that of the Northern Song Dynasty.

translations.zh: 造型求变的五代瓷器五代十国虽然历时不长，而且是中国历史上一段大分裂时期，但陶瓷制作技艺却很出色。
translations.en: Seeking Innovation: Porcelain of the Five Dynasties Short-lived and riven by political division, the Five Dynasties and Ten States nonetheless boasted ceramics of outstanding craftsmanship.

translations.zh: 越窑、耀州窑青瓷常以刻划花技法进行装饰，为宋代瓷器刻划花装饰的流行奠定了基础。
translations.en: The popular carved and incised patterns on celadon from the Yue and Yaozhou kilns were the predecessors of those in the Song Dynasty.

translations.zh: 实用美观的唐代其他窑陶瓷唐代湖南岳州窑和长沙窑、江西洪州窑、安徽寿州窑、河南巩县窑、陕西耀州窑和鼎州窑等，均为称誉一时的著名陶瓷窑场。
translations.en: During the Tang Dynasty, the kilns at Yuezhou and Changsha in Hunan, at Hongzhou in Jiangxi, at Shouzhou in Anhui, at Gongxian in Henan, and at Yaozhou and Dingzhou in Shaanxi were all famous.

translations.zh: 特别是釉下彩绘瓷的大量烧造，为瓷器装饰开辟了一条新的途径。
translations.en: The large production of the underglaze designs provided new possibilities for porcelain decoration.

translations.zh: 唐代浙江越窑、湖南长沙窑、四川邛崃窑等均曾烧造过此类产品，尤以长沙窑最为著名，产量也最大，产品行销海内外。
translations.en: The Yue kilns in Zhejiang, Changsha kilns in Hunan, and Qionglai kilns in Sichuan all manufactured underglaze painted celadon in the Tang Dynasty.

translations.zh: 1998年在印度尼西亚勿里洞岛海域发现的“黑石号”沉船中，打捞出6万多件中国唐代瓷器，有5万多件长沙窑产品，其中即包括大量釉下彩青瓷。
translations.en: Among these, the Changsha kilns were the most famous and had the largest production, with its products sold both at home and abroad.

source.title_zh: 承前启后的隋代青瓷和白瓷
source.title_en: Inheriting and Breaking Through: Celadon and White Porcelain in the Sui Dynasty

translations.zh: 隋代瓷器以青瓷为主，南北方均有烧造。
translations.en: Celadon dominated Sui Dynasty porcelain production in both the north and south.

source.title_zh: 承前启后的隋代青瓷和白瓷
source.title_en: Inheriting and Breaking Through: Celadon and White Porcelain in the Sui Dynasty

translations.zh: 隋代白瓷质量进一步提高，主要表现在造型更加规整、胎质更显洁白细腻、釉质愈发匀净光亮。
translations.en: White porcelain became finer and more expertly produced, featuring a fine-textured body with an even and smooth glaze coating.

source.title_zh: 承前启后的隋代青瓷和白瓷
source.title_en: Inheriting and Breaking Through: Celadon and White Porcelain in the Sui Dynasty

translations.zh: 盘口四系瓶、双联瓶、高足盘等，均堪称隋代陶瓷中具有鲜明时代特征的造型
translations.en: Typical pieces of this period include the plate-mouthed vase with four loop-ears and the stem plate.

translations.zh: “类银类雪”的邢窑白瓷“类玉类冰”的越窑青瓷和唐代，瓷器已成为最重要的日常生活用器之一。
translations.en: Jade-like Celadon of the Yue Kiln and Snow-like White Porcelain of the Xing Kiln Porcelain wares were widely used in daily life in the Tang Dynasty.

translations.zh: 代表当时最高制瓷工艺水平的是南方主要烧造青瓷的越窑和北方主要烧造白瓷的邢窑，唐代茶圣陆羽《茶经》形容越窑青瓷“类玉类冰”、邢窑白瓷“类银类雪”。
translations.en: Celadon from the Yue kiln in the south and white porcelain from the Xing kiln in the north represented the highest technical level of the period, and were greatly valued.

translations.zh: 斑驳陆离的“唐三彩”“唐三彩”系唐代多色釉陶的简称，是唐代陶瓷中的著名品种。
translations.en: Tri-colour Pottery in the Tang Dynasty The polychrome glaze wares of the Tang Dynasty are commonly known as tri-colour pottery (sancai), and tombs in Henan and Shaanxi have yielded a large concentration of burial objects in this style.

translations.zh: “唐三彩”主要发现于河南、陕西唐代墓葬中，多为随葬用明器，造型繁多、釉色华丽，具有较高的艺术价值。
translations.en: Lead oxide functioned as the flux and oxides of other metals such as copper, iron, cobalt, and manganese served as colour reagents.

translations.zh: “唐三彩”釉以氧化铅（PbO）作主要助熔剂，以铜、铁、钻、锰等金属的氧化物作主要着色剂。
translations.en: After firing, the glaze took on various hues, such as green, blue, yellow, brown, white, and black, in different shades.

translations.zh: 先将胎体入窑经约1000～1100℃素烧，施釉后再入窑经约800～900℃釉烧。
translations.en: A tri-colour pottery article looks splendid with its polychrome designs Tri-colour pottery wares mainly included plates, bowls, cups, lamps, pillows, jars, and human and animal figurines

translations.zh: 承前启后的隋代青瓷和白瓷隋代瓷器以青瓷为主，南北方均有烧造。
translations.en: Inheriting and Breaking Through: Celadon and White Porcelain in the Sui Dynasty Celadon dominated Sui Dynasty porcelain production in both the north and south.

translations.zh: 装饰多以简单的刻、划花为主，常用朵花与几何纹或草叶纹等相间排列，组成团状或带状图案，时代特征鲜明。
translations.en: White porcelain became finer and more expertly produced, featuring a fine-textured body with an even and smooth glaze coating.

translations.zh: 隋代白瓷质量进一步提高，主要表现在造型更加规整、胎质更显洁白细腻、釉质愈发匀净光亮。
translations.en: Typical pieces of this period include the plate-mouthed vase with four loop-ears and the stem plate

translations.zh: 南北朝陶瓷南朝瓷器品种仍以青瓷为主。
translations.en: Ceramics of the Southern and Northern Dynasties (420-589) Celadon remained the major ceramic product in the kingdoms in the south, whereas the northern kingdoms saw a wider variety, with black and white-glazed Wares alongside the green of celadon.

translations.zh: 北朝瓷器品种有青釉、黑釉和白釉瓷等。
translations.en: Potters from the Northern Dynasties invented white porcelain and moreover further developed low-temperature lead-glazed pottery.

translations.zh: 由于南北方在配制青瓷胎、釉所用原料方面均有不同，使得二者呈色亦有区别。
translations.en: It was not uncommon to see glaze in two colours on the same pottery piece.

translations.zh: 南方青瓷釉色青翠，北方青瓷玻璃质感较强。
translations.en: This technique would later be developed into the art of tri-colour pottery in the Tang Dynasty

translations.zh: 三国、两晋陶瓷浙江既是瓷器的发源地，也是三国、两晋时期瓷器生产的中心。
translations.en: Porcelain production was concentrated in Zhejiang during the Three Kingdoms Period and Eastern Jin Dynasty (317-420).

translations.zh: 这一时期的浙江瓷窑除大量烧造精美的青瓷外，还烧造少量黑釉瓷。
translations.en: In addition to exquisite celadon wares in large quantities, black-glazed wares were also manufactured in Zhejiang kilns, with the Deqing kiln site a characteristic example

source.title_zh: 南青北白隋、唐、五代陶瓷（公元581~960年）
source.title_en: Celadon in the South and Whiteware in the North Ceramics of the Sui and Tang and Five Dynasties

translations.zh: 纹等相间质更显洁型。
translations.en: featuring a template.

source.title_zh: 南青北白隋、唐、五代陶瓷（公元581~960年）
source.title_en: Celadon in the South and Whiteware in the North Ceramics of the Sui and Tang and Five Dynasties

translations.zh: 隋代陶瓷生产承前启后，无论在造型还是装饰方面，均呈现出鲜明的时代特点。
translations.en: Porcelain production in the Sui Dynasty (581-618) broke new ground with its distinctive features.

source.title_zh: 南青北白隋、唐、五代陶瓷（公元581~960年）
source.title_en: Celadon in the South and Whiteware in the North Ceramics of the Sui and Tang and Five Dynasties

translations.zh: 唐代是中国陶瓷生产蓬勃发展时期，瓷窑遍布全国各地，器物造型千姿百态、纹饰丰富优美。
translations.en: The art of ceramics flourished further during the following Tang Dynasty (618-907), during which porcelain wares were widely used in daily life and as burial objects.

source.title_zh: 南青北白隋、唐、五代陶瓷（公元581~960年）
source.title_en: Celadon in the South and Whiteware in the North Ceramics of the Sui and Tang and Five Dynasties

translations.zh: 饮茶风俗的普及和饮酒风气的盛行，进一步刺激了制瓷业的发展。
translations.en: The widespread habits of tea and wine-drinking boosted the development of porcelain production,

source.title_zh: 南青北白隋、唐、五代陶瓷（公元581~960年）
source.title_en: Celadon in the South and Whiteware in the North Ceramics of the Sui and Tang and Five Dynasties

translations.zh: 中外经济、文化的交流和发展，更使中国陶瓷作为特产而开始大量销往亚、非地区，成为中外友好往来的物证。
translations.en: while economic and cultural exchanges made ceramics a manifestation of friendly relations between China and foreign countries.

source.title_zh: 南青北白隋、唐、五代陶瓷（公元581~960年）
source.title_en: Celadon in the South and Whiteware in the North Ceramics of the Sui and Tang and Five Dynasties

translations.zh: 五代时期的陶瓷继承唐末遗风，不但胎体明显变薄，而且更加注重器物造型的优美和装饰工艺的精细，为宋代陶瓷生产高峰的出现奠定了工艺基础。
translations.en: exquisite decoration, technically preparing the ground for the zenith of ceramic art in the Song Dynasty

source.title_zh: 青瓷初秀
source.title_en: Ceramics of Three Kingdoms Period, Jin Dynasty, and the Southern and Northern Dynasties

translations.zh: 青瓷初秀三国、两晋、南北朝陶瓷（公元220年～589年）出现于夏、商之际的原始瓷，经过西周、春秋、战国、西汉的发展，至东汉已普遍演进为符合现代标准的成熟瓷器。
translations.en: Ceramics of Three Kingdoms Period, Jin Dynasty, and the Southern and Northern Dynasties By the Eastern Han Dynasty,the proto-porcelain that began in the Xia and Shang dynasties had developed into what we know today as porcelain.

source.title_zh: 青瓷初秀
source.title_en: Ceramics of Three Kingdoms Period, Jin Dynasty, and the Southern and Northern Dynasties

translations.zh: 三国、两晋、南北朝历时360余年，陶瓷生产发展迅速，主要表现在南方制瓷技术明显提高，产区和规模不断扩大，江苏、浙江、福建、江西、湖南、湖北、四川等省境内均有窑址分布。
translations.en: Porcelain-making in the south developed substantially during the Three Kingdoms Period, Jin Dynasty, and the Southern and Northern Dynasties.

source.title_zh: 青瓷初秀
source.title_en: Ceramics of Three Kingdoms Period, Jin Dynasty, and the Southern and Northern Dynasties

translations.zh: 瓷器品种主要为青瓷，也有少量黑瓷。
translations.en: Celadon was the major type, with some black-glazed porcelain, and the items were largely for daily use or for burial.

source.title_zh: 青瓷初秀
source.title_en: Ceramics of Three Kingdoms Period, Jin Dynasty, and the Southern and Northern Dynasties

translations.zh: 器物造型以日常生活和随葬用盘、碗、榻（gé，音：格）、洗、壶、罐、烛台、虎子、睡壶、熏炉、谷仓、人物俑、动物俑等为主，产品各具地方特色。
translations.en: Each production site gave its products distinct features.

source.title_zh: 青瓷初秀
source.title_en: Ceramics of Three Kingdoms Period, Jin Dynasty, and the Southern and Northern Dynasties

translations.zh: 河南省安阳市北齐武平六年（575年）骠骑大将军范粹（548～575年）墓出土的白瓷，是目前已知我国最早的白瓷，为隋、唐时期白瓷的发展奠定了基础。
translations.en: The white porcelain excavated from the tomb of the Cavalry General Fan Cui (548-575) dating back to 575 (the sixth year of the Wuping era in the Northern Qi Dynasty) in Anyang, Henan Province, is the earliest known of its kind.

translations.zh: 瓷器的发明1976年，考古工作者在浙江省上虞县发现东汉晚期青瓷窑址，科技工作者对出土瓷片进行科学检测的结果表明，其烧成温度已达1300℃（±20℃），显气孔率0.62%，吸水率0.28%，抗弯强度710kg/cm²，胎体中氧化铁（Fe₂O₃）含量1.64%，二氧化钛（TiO₂）含量0.97%。
translations.en: Early Porcelain In 1976, archaeologists discovered a celadon kiln site from the late Eastern Han Dynasty in Shangyu County Zhejiang Province.

translations.zh: 这些数据证明，最迟在东汉晚期，我国已能够普遍烧造基本符合现代标准的瓷器。
translations.en: Scientific testing on the excavated porcelain fragments showed that the kiln's products were true porcelain, proving that what we now know as porcelain was successfully manufactured in China by the late Eastern Han Dynasty at the latest.

translations.zh: 原始瓷的出现和发展
translations.en: The Emergence and Development of Proto-porcelain

translations.zh: 原始瓷出现于夏末商初，系以瓷土作胎、器表施一层透明草木灰釉或石灰釉、入窑经1200℃以上温度焙烧而成的窑器。
translations.en: Emerging around the turning of the Xia and Shang dynasties, proto-porcelain was made of porcelain clay and coated with a layer of transparent ash or lime glaze.

translations.zh: 其胎质坚硬、器表光亮，但与成熟瓷器相比，在胎体吸水率、机械强度、烧成温度等方面仍带有一定的原始性，故被称作“原始瓷”。
translations.en: It was then baked at a temperature above 1200°C.

translations.zh: 西周、春秋、战国、西汉时期，原始瓷产量增加，质量亦不断提高，浙江、江苏、江西、福建、台湾、广东、广西和湖南等地，均曾出土过这一时期的原始瓷。
translations.en: In the Zhou and Western Han dynasties, proto-porcelain production increased in scale and in quality.

translations.zh: 汉代彩绘陶和低温铅釉陶彩绘陶系指在已烧成的陶器上用天然矿物颜料描绘纹饰后不再入窑焙烧的陶器。
translations.en: Colour-painted Pottery and Low-temperature Lead-glazed Pottery in the Han Dynasty Colour-painted pottery refers to pottery that was painted with patterns using natural mineral pigments after baking.

translations.zh: 早在新石器时代的一些遗址里已有发现，战国、秦、汉时期兴盛。
translations.en: Manufacturing thrived in the Warring States Period and Qin and Han dynasties, with designs largely following those of contemporary lacquer ware.

translations.zh: 低温铅釉陶器亦属于陪葬用明器。
translations.en: Low-temperature lead-glazed pottery first appeared in Shaanxi during the Western Han Dynasty and was used to make burial objects.

translations.zh: 釉色主要有黄、绿两种，分别以氧化铁（Fe₂O₃）和氧化铜（CuO）作呈色剂，均以氧化铅（PbO）作助熔剂，烧成温度约为700～900℃，釉面光亮。
translations.en: Ferric oxide (Fe₂O₃) and copper oxide (CuO) were used as colour reagents for yellow-and green-coloured pottery, respectively, with litharge (PbO) as the flux.

translations.zh: 造型多模仿同时期的漆器和青铜器，给人耳目一新之感。
translations.en: Baked at a temperature of 700-900°C, the pottery was characterized by its translucent glaze surface.The shape was usually modelled on lacquerware or bronze.

source.title_zh: 色彩斑斓的花釉瓷
source.title_en: Polychrome Speckle-glazed Ceramics

translations.zh: 花釉系指在黑釉、黄釉、天蓝色釉或茶叶末釉等底釉上用点、绘、淋、涂等方法装饰月白釉或天蓝釉的一种装饰釉。
translations.en: Speckle-glaze refers to a decorative glaze in diverse colours.

source.title_zh: 色彩斑斓的花釉瓷
source.title_en: Polychrome Speckle-glazed Ceramics

translations.zh: 烧成后，釉色交融浸润，色彩变化莫测。
translations.en: It was the result of dotting, daubing, or spraying pale blue or azure glaze on a ground of black, yellow, azure, or tea-dust glaze.

source.title_zh: 色彩斑斓的花釉瓷
source.title_en: Polychrome Speckle-glazed Ceramics

translations.zh: 陶瓷腰鼓是唐代流行乐器之一，以河南鲁山窑烧造者最有名气，唐人南卓《羯鼓录》对其有记载。
translations.en: The ceramic drum was a popular Tang musical instrument, with the most renowned examples produced at the Lushan kiln in Henan.

translations.zh: 商代刻纹白陶和灰陶刻纹白陶出现于商代晚期，其胎体所用原料是一种氧化铁（FeO）含量很低的粘土，烧成温度在1000℃左右。
translations.en: Engraved White Pottery and Grey Pottery in the Shang Dynasty White pottery engraved with patterns,which first appeared in the late Shang period, was made of a kind of clay with a low ferric oxide content (Fe2O3) and baked at around 1000°C.

translations.zh: 胎质洁白细腻，造型、纹饰均模仿当时的青铜器。
translations.en: In shape and pattern, these items were modelled on bronzes.

translations.zh: 主要出土于河南安阳地区商代晚期墓葬，属于王室和贵族的专用品。
translations.en: They have chiefly been excavated from the late Shang tombs at Anyang, Henan Province, and were reserved for royalty and the nobility made in the Shang Dynasty

translations.zh: 古老神秘的彩陶艺术彩陶系指画有黑、红、白、褐等色纹饰的陶器。
translations.en: Magnificent and Mysterious Painted Pottery "Painted pottery" refers to pottery articles painted with black, red, white, and brown decorative patterns.

translations.zh: 在成型后的陶坯上用毛笔蘸彩料描画纹饰后，入窑经900℃左右的温度焙烧而成。
translations.en: After painting, the clay was baked at around 900°C.

translations.zh: 它是中国陶瓷工艺史上最早把装饰纹样与造型结合在一起的艺术品，堪称远古文化艺术的第一个高峰。
translations.en: In the history of Chinese ceramic technology, painted pottery is the earliest to combine decoration with artifacts. This can be called the first peak of ancient art.

translations.zh: 第八期第七期精巧的制陶工艺第六期第五期新石器时代中晚期，制陶工艺技术日趋娴熟，原料的精选、快轮拉坯技术的发明，使陶器造型更加丰富，形体愈加规整。
translations.en: Exquisite Ceramic Technology Through the middle and late Neolithic, ceramic production grew increasingly refined.

translations.zh: 大汶口文化白陶系使用一种氧化铁（Fe2O）含量极低第四期的粘土成型后，入窑经1000℃左右的温度焙烧而成。
translations.en: Examples included the white pottery wares of the Dawenkou culture, made of a kind of clay with a low ferric oxide content (Fe2O3) and baked at around 1000°C,

translations.zh: 龙山文化黑陶，系用快轮拉坯成型，胎壁薄者厚度仅0.3～1毫米，故有“蛋壳黑陶”之美称，反映出当时精湛的成型技艺。
translations.en: and the black pottery of the Longshan culture, turned on a potter's wheel and characterized by its extremely thin wall of only 0.3mm to 1mm thick.It is hence termed "eggshell black pottery

source.title_zh: 瓷苑序曲夏、商、周、秦、汉陶瓷（约公元前2100年～公元220年）
source.title_en: Prelude Ceramics in the Xia, Shang, Zhou, Qin, and Han Dynasties (C.2100 BCE-220 CE)

translations.zh: 商代除大量烧造灰陶以外，还烧造精美的刻纹白陶和印纹硬陶。
translations.en: The Shang Dynasty (C. 16th century BCE-11th century BCE) saw the production of great amounts of grey pottery as well as engraved white pottery and hard pottery with impressed decoration.

source.title_zh: 瓷苑序曲夏、商、周、秦、汉陶瓷（约公元前2100年～公元220年）
source.title_en: Prelude Ceramics in the Xia, Shang, Zhou, Qin, and Han Dynasties (C.2100 BCE-220 CE)

translations.zh: 约在夏、商之际出现了原始瓷，为后来成熟瓷器的发明奠定了基础。
translations.en: Proto-porcelain came into being around the turning of the Xia and Shang dynasties, leading to the later development of true porcelain.

source.title_zh: 瓷苑序曲夏、商、周、秦、汉陶瓷（约公元前2100年～公元220年）
source.title_en: Prelude Ceramics in the Xia, Shang, Zhou, Qin, and Han Dynasties (C.2100 BCE-220 CE)

translations.zh: 战国时期，陶瓷生产更加专业化，印纹硬陶和原始瓷在南方获得普遍发展。
translations.en: The Warring States Period (475 BCE-221 BCE) witnessed a great development of impressed hard pottery and of proto-porcelain in the south, while the terracotta warriors of the Qin Mausoleum exemplify the superb pottery art of the subsequent Qin Dynasty (221 BCE-206 BCE).

source.title_zh: 瓷苑序曲夏、商、周、秦、汉陶瓷（约公元前2100年～公元220年）
source.title_en: Prelude Ceramics in the Xia, Shang, Zhou, Qin, and Han Dynasties (C.2100 BCE-220 CE)

translations.zh: 西汉时期，我国北方发明的低温铅釉陶，为后来低温釉彩的发展奠定了工艺基础。
translations.en: Low-temperature lead-glazed pottery was first made in the north during the Western Han Dynasty (206 BCE-8 CE).

source.title_zh: 瓷苑序曲夏、商、周、秦、汉陶瓷（约公元前2100年～公元220年）
source.title_en: Prelude Ceramics in the Xia, Shang, Zhou, Qin, and Han Dynasties (C.2100 BCE-220 CE)

translations.zh: 东汉时期，成熟瓷器的批量烧造，堪称中国乃至世界陶瓷发展史上的一个重要里程碑，也是中华民族对人类文明做出的杰出贡献之一。
translations.en: This was followed by a significant achievement in global ceramics history, when true porcelain was successfully produced in large quantities in the Eastern Han Dynasty (25-220).

source.title_zh: 追踪溯源新石器时代陶器（约公元前8000年前2000年）
source.title_en: Tracing the Source Neolithic Pottery (C.8000BCE-2000BCE)

translations.zh: 陶器是随着人类对大自然的认识不断提高而产生。
translations.en: Pottery is the product of humanity's ever-increasing understanding of the natural world.

source.title_zh: 追踪溯源新石器时代陶器（约公元前8000年前2000年）
source.title_en: Tracing the Source Neolithic Pottery (C.8000BCE-2000BCE)

translations.zh: 考古发现所获得的资料证明，我国的陶器生产距今已有约两万年的历史，陶器是原始先民主要的日常生产和生活用具。
translations.en: Archaeological discoveries have confirmed that pottery utensils for daily life.

source.title_zh: 追踪溯源新石器时代陶器（约公元前8000年前2000年）
source.title_en: Tracing the Source Neolithic Pottery (C.8000BCE-2000BCE)

translations.zh: 进入新石器时代，制陶术在我国获得很大发展。
translations.en: Sites of Neolithic cultures have been widely found across China, primarily in the Yellow River Valley, Yangtze River Valley, coastal areas in the southeast, and northern areas.

source.title_zh: 追踪溯源新石器时代陶器（约公元前8000年前2000年）
source.title_en: Tracing the Source Neolithic Pottery (C.8000BCE-2000BCE)

translations.zh: 在黄河流域、长江流域、东南沿海和北方地区的新石器时代文化遗址中，均出土过丰富的实物资料，其中即包括大量陶器。
translations.en: The pottery articles made in different culturally interrelated

translations.zh: 文华殿始建于明初，与武英殿东西遥对。
translations.en: Hall of Literary Brilliance [Wenhua dian] Built in the early Ming Dynasty, this hall, and the Hall of Martial Valour (Wuying dian), located symmetrically on the east and west sides of the Forbidden City central axis respectively.

translations.zh: 明末毁于李自成焚宫，清康熙二十二年（1683年）重建。
translations.en: At the end of the Ming, it was destroyed in a fire set at the order of Li Zicheng, the peasant rebel leader who intended to burn down the entire Forbidden City, before being rebuilt in the Qing Dynasty in 1683, during the Kangxi Emperor's reign.

translations.zh: 前后殿呈工字型结构，东西配殿分别是本仁殿、集义殿。
translations.en: The front and rear halls together form an H-shaped structure; the eastern and western side halls are named the Hall of Original Benevolence (Benren dian) and the Hall of Collected Righteousness (Jiyi dian) respectively.

translations.zh: 按五行学说，东方属木，主生长，这里在明代曾一度作为太子东宫，亦曾用作皇帝的便殿。
translations.en: Following the Theory of the Five Elements, the east is associated with wood and governs growth.

translations.zh: 明清两代更多的是于春秋仲月在此举行经典礼，此外殿试阅卷也曾在文华殿进行。
translations.en: As a result, this hall was used during the Ming as a residence for the crown prince, as well as a place of leisure for the emperor.

translations.zh: 内金水桥内金水桥，位于太和门前的五座石桥。
translations.en: Inner Golden Water Bridges [Neijinshui qiao] The Inner Golden Water Bridges, built in the early Ming Dynasty (1368-1644), refer to the five single-arched stone bridges in front of the Gate of Supreme Harmony (Taihe men), under which flows the river of their namesake.

translations.zh: 桥为单拱券式，居中一座为御路桥，供皇帝通行，桥长20余米，宽约6米，两侧汉白玉栏杆，望柱头雕云龙纹饰，形制等级为五桥之首。
translations.en: The bridge in the middle was exclusively reserved for the emperor.

translations.zh: 其东西两侧各有桥两座，长宽依次递减，望柱头为二十四气纹饰，为王公大臣、文武官员等通行之桥。
translations.en: The finest of the five, it is over 20 meters long and around six meters wide, with a white marble balustrade on each side decorated with cloud-and-dragon designs.The bridges on either side were for nobles, ministers, and civil and military officials, with their length and width in inverse relationship to their distance from the central one.

translations.zh: 太和门紫禁城外朝正门。
translations.en: Gate of Supreme Harmony (Taihe men) The main gate of the Forbidden City's Outer Court, the Gate of Supreme Harmony (Taihe men) was built in 1420 in the early Ming dynasty.

translations.zh: 明永乐十八年（1420年）建成，初名奉天门，明嘉靖四十一年（1562年）改称皇极门。
translations.en: It was initially named the Gate of Venerating Heaven(Fengtian men),and then in 1562, renamed the Gate of Imperial Supremacy (Huangji men).

translations.zh: 在明代为皇帝早朝“御门听政”处。
translations.en: During the Ming dynasty, the emperor held morning court at this gate to listen to briefings from his officials.

translations.zh: 清顺治元年（1644年），顺治帝在此举行入关后的登极典礼，并颁布诏书大赦天下。
translations.en: In 1644, the first year of the Shunzhi Emperor's reign at the beginning of the Qing dynasty, the emperor held his enthronement ceremony and declared general amnesty here.

translations.zh: 清顺治二年（1645年）始称太和门，清光绪十四年（1888年）毁于火，次年重建
translations.en: In the following year, the gate received its present name. In 1888, the fourteenth year of the Guangxu Emperor's reign, it was destroyed in a fire, and was rebuilt a year later.

translations.zh: 昭德门及太和始建于明永乐十八年（1420年），初名东角门，嘉靖四十一年（1562年）改称弘政门，清顺治二年（1645年）始名昭德门。
translations.en: Hall of Supreme Harmony (Taihe) Hall of Middle Harmony (Zhonghe) Hall of Preserving Harmony (Baohe) Gate of Manifest Virtue (Zhaodemen) Built in the Ming Dynasty in 1420, the eighteenth year of the Yongle Emperor's reign, this gate was originally named East Palace Corner Gate (Dongjiao men), renamed the Gate of Spreading Heavenly Governance (Hongzheng men) in 1562 under the Jiajing Emperor, and acquired its current name in the Qing (1644-1911) under the Shunzhi Emperor's rule in 1645.

translations.zh: 昭德，意为彰明美德。
translations.en: Zhaode means to make virtues manifest.

translations.zh: 光绪十四年（1888年）毁于火，次年重建。
translations.en: The gate was destroyed in a fire during the Guangxu reign in 1888, and rebuilt in the following year.

translations.zh: 明代为选拔国家礼仪官员即考选鸿胪之地。
translations.en: In the Ming Dynasty, this was the site for testing and selecting officials in charge of state ceremonies, or Honglu.

translations.zh: 清代为侍卫值宿处。
translations.en: In the Qing Dynasty, imperial guards were stationed here on night duty.

translations.zh: 保和 乾清 交泰 坤宁
translations.en: Palace of Heavenly Purity (Qianqing) Hall of Union (Jiaotai) Palace of Earthly Tranquility (Kunning)

source.title_zh: 故宫博物院简介
source.title_en: The Palace Museum

translations.zh: 故宫博物院成立于1925年，是在明清皇宫及其收藏基础上建立起来的国家级大型综合性博物馆。
translations.en: Established in 1925, the Palace Museum is a comprehensive museum of traditional Chinese art.

source.title_zh: 故宫博物院简介
source.title_en: The Palace Museum

translations.zh: 故宫于1961年被国务院列为第一批“全国重点文物保护单位”，1987年被联合国教科文组织列入“世界遗产名录”。
translations.en: It is based on the site of the Forbidden City, the imperial palace of the Ming and Qing dynasties for nearly five centuries, and draws on the vast imperial art collections.

source.title_zh: 故宫博物院简介
source.title_en: The Palace Museum

translations.zh: 故宫博物院占地100余万平方米，保存古建筑约9000间，是我国现存规模最大、保存最完整的古代宫殿建筑群。
translations.en: Covering over one million square metres, the Ming and Qing architectural compound under the Palace Museum's administration consists of around 9000 bays (internal spaces defined by four columns) of heritage structures, making it China's largest and best-preserved historical palace complex.

source.title_zh: 故宫博物院简介
source.title_en: The Palace Museum

translations.zh: 其前身明清皇宫紫禁城，于明永乐十八年（1420年）建成，分为外朝和内廷两部分，外朝以太和殿、中和殿、保和殿为主体，文华殿、武英殿为两翼，主要是皇帝举行盛大典礼的场所。
translations.en: The Forbidden City, on the site of which the Museum was born, was completed in 1420, the eighteenth year of the Yongle reign in the Ming Dynasty.

source.title_zh: 故宫博物院简介
source.title_en: The Palace Museum

translations.zh: 内廷以乾清宫、交泰殿、坤宁宫为主体，东西六宫为两翼，是皇帝处理日常政务以及帝后妃嫔生活起居的地方。
translations.en: It is composed of an Outer Court and Inner Court.

source.title_zh: 故宫博物院简介
source.title_en: The Palace Museum

translations.zh: 此外还有外东路的太上皇宫和外西路的太后宫院等处。
translations.en: The Outer Court hosted grand ceremonies and rituals.

source.title_zh: 故宫博物院简介
source.title_en: The Palace Museum

translations.zh: 明清两代共有24位皇帝居住于此，1912年清朝灭亡后，紫禁城作为皇宫的历史就此终结。
translations.en: Following its completion, the Forbidden City served as residence for a total of 24 Ming and Qing emperors, before its role came to end after the Qing Dynasty was overthrown in 1912.

source.title_zh: 故宫博物院简介
source.title_en: The Palace Museum

translations.zh: 1914年，于外朝区域成立古物陈列所；1925年，于内廷区域成立故宫博物院：1948年，古物陈列所并入故宫博物院。
translations.en: In 1914, the National Museum (Guwu Chenliesuo) was established in the Outer Court and opened to the public.

source.title_zh: 故宫博物院简介
source.title_en: The Palace Museum

translations.zh: 故宫博物院院藏文物体系完备，现有藏品总量186万余件（套），藏品总分25大类别，堪称艺术的宝库。
translations.en: Today, the Palace Museum possesses an all-encompassing collection numbering over 1.86 million items (or sets of items) across 25 major categories; it is truly an artistic treasure trove.

source.title_zh: 故宫博物院简介
source.title_en: The Palace Museum

translations.zh: 故宫博物院通过明清皇家宫殿建筑，宫廷史迹原状陈列，珍宝、钟表、书画、陶瓷、雕塑等艺术藏品专馆陈设，以及专题展览等多种方式向公众展现悠久灿烂的中华文明。
translations.en: It showcases China's age-old and splendid civilization to the public through imperial palace architecture, the reproduction of original interior settings, permanent exhibitions including decorative arts, timepieces, paintings, calligraphy, ceramics, and sculptures, and special The Palace Museum exhibitions.

source.title_zh: 故宫博物院简介
source.title_en: The Palace Museum

translations.zh: 故宫观众自动导游观众服务
translations.en: Audio Guide Visitor Service

source.title_zh: 铜缸、铁缸
source.title_en: Bronze and Iron Vats

translations.zh: 铜缸、铁缸是宫中的防火设备之一，平时贮满清水，以备灭火时用。
translations.en: Usually filled with water, these bronze and iron vats were used to protect the imperial palace from fire.

source.title_zh: 铜缸、铁缸
source.title_en: Bronze and Iron Vats

translations.zh: 每到冬季小雪节气至翌年惊蛰，在缸外套上棉套，缸上加盖，气温低时，缸下烧炭加温，以防缸水冻结。
translations.en: Between Xiaoxue (Light Snow) and Jingzhe (Awakening of Insects) in solar terms, the vats were wrapped in cotton cloth and covered with a lid.

source.title_zh: 铜缸、铁缸
source.title_en: Bronze and Iron Vats

translations.zh: 紫禁城内现存最早的缸为明弘治年间铸造。
translations.en: When necessary, charcoal would also be burnt underneath to prevent the water from freezing.

source.title_zh: 铜缸、铁缸
source.title_en: Bronze and Iron Vats

translations.zh: 明代的缸两耳均加素面铁环，样式上奢下敛，古朴大方。
translations.en: The earliest vat now preserved in the Forbidden City was cast during the Hongzhi reign (1488-1505)in the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644).

source.title_zh: 铜缸、铁缸
source.title_en: Bronze and Iron Vats

translations.zh: 清代的缸两耳多加兽面环，腹大口收。
translations.en: Ming vats are simple yet elegant, with plain iron rings on the sides and a wider upper body with a tapered base.

source.title_zh: 铜缸、铁缸
source.title_en: Bronze and Iron Vats

translations.zh: 宫中现设大小铜、铁、鎏金铜缸共二百余口，其中鎏金铜缸22口，分别陈设在太和殿、保和殿、乾清门和乾清宫两边。
translations.en: Qing Dynasty (1644-1911)vats feature rings held by side knobs with the faces of beasts, a large belly and a smaller mouth.

source.title_zh: 铜缸、铁缸
source.title_en: Bronze and Iron Vats

translations.zh: 爱护文物、古建请勿攀爬、刻画
translations.en: At present there are over 200 bronze and iron vats in the Palace Museum, including twenty-two gilt bronze ones flanking the Hall of Supreme Harmony (Taihe dian), the Hall of Preserving Harmony (Baohe dian), the Gate of Heavenly Purity (Qianqing men) and the Palace of Heavenly Purity (Qianqing gong).

translations.zh: 太和殿俗称金銮殿，是明清两代举行重大典礼活动的场所。
translations.en: Hall of Supreme Harmony (Taihe dian) Commonly known as the Hall of Golden Chimes (Jinluan dian), the Hall of Supreme Harmony was the site of grand ceremonies in the Ming and Qing dynasties.

translations.zh: 明永乐十八年（1420年）建成，初称奉天殿，明嘉靖四十一年（1562年）改称皇极殿，清顺治二年（1645年）始名太和殿。
translations.en: It was built in the Ming Dynasty in 1420, the 18th year of the Yongle Emperor's reign, and was initially called the Hall of Venerating Heaven (Fengtian dian).

translations.zh: “太和”出自《周易》，意即天地万物和谐运行。
translations.en: In 1562, the 41st year of the Jiajing Emperor's reign, it was renamed the Hall of Imperial Supremacy (Huangji dian), and it finally received its present name in 1645, the second year of the Qing Dynasty Shunzhi Emperor's reign.

translations.zh: 每年元旦、冬至、万寿（皇帝生日）三大节以及皇帝登基、大婚、册立皇后、宣布进士名次、命将出征等重大活动都在此举行。
translations.en: Supreme harmony' derives from the ancient divination text the Book of Changes (I Ching or Yi Jing), in which it refers to the harmonious co-existence of all beings in heaven and on earth.

translations.zh: 太和殿坐落在三层汉白玉台基之上，殿高26.92米，建筑面积2377平方米，是故宫现存等级最高的古代建筑。
translations.en: The Hall of Supreme Harmony, standing on three-layered white marble terraces, is 26.92 meters high and covers an area of 2,377 square meters.

translations.zh: 宫殿檐角安放10个脊兽，成为此类建筑装饰中等级最高的孤例。
translations.en: It is the highest-ranking heritage structure extant in the Forbidden City, and accordingly the eaves feature the highest level of imperial decoration, with ten figurines on each corner, a practice unique to this building.

translations.zh: 殿内正中为雕龙金漆宝座，上方悬挂乾隆帝御笔“建极绥献”匾，四周矗立六根“沥粉贴金”盘龙柱。
translations.en: A gold-lacquered throne carved with dragon designs occupies the center of the hall.

translations.zh: 殿顶天花正中的藻井雕有口衔宝珠（又称“轩镜”）俯首下视的蟠龙。
translations.en: Above it hangs a tablet bearing the inscription establish the highest principles and bring peace' (jian ji sui you) in the Qianlong Emperor's hand.

translations.zh: 殿内铺苏州产细料澄泥方砖，俗称“金砖”。
translations.en: Six columns decorated with golden coiled dragons surround the imperial throne.

translations.zh: 太和殿几经焚毁、重建，现为清康熙三十四年（1695年）重建后的形制。
translations.en: The Hall of Supreme Harmony has been burned down and rebuilt several times.

translations.zh: 扫一扫，听听它的故事
translations.en: Large Stone Carving [Dashidiao]

translations.zh: 大石雕保和殿后石雕分为上、中、下三块，其中最下方的石雕长16.57米、宽3.07米、厚1.70米，重约200吨，是紫禁城中最大的一块，俗称大石雕。
translations.en: The stone carving behind the Hall of Preserving Harmony (Baohe dian) is divided into upper, middle and lower sections.

translations.zh: 现有花纹图案为清乾隆二十五年（1760年）重新雕刻。
translations.en: The lower section measures 16.57 metres long, 3.07 metres wide and 1.70 metres deep, and weighs around 200 tons.

translations.zh: 大石雕主体雕刻九条蟠龙腾飞于流云之中，下端为海水江崖图案，四周饰以番草纹饰。
translations.en: It is the largest of its kind in the Forbidden City, hence the colloquial name 'Large Stone Carving'.

translations.zh: 大石雕的石料采自北京房山大石窝，距紫禁城80余公里。
translations.en: The patterns we see today were re-carved in 1760, the 25th year of the Qianlong Emperor's reign during the Qing Dynasty.

translations.zh: 据记载，当时要运送类似体量的石料，需动用2万民夫造“早船”拖拽，历时28日才能将石料运到紫禁城。
translations.en: The grand carving is dominated by nine coiled dragons among billowing clouds, with a 'waves and mountains' (haishui jiangya) pattern at the bottom and curling grass pattern around the edge.

translations.zh: 保和殿明永乐十八年（1420年）建成，几经焚毁、重建。
translations.en: Hall of Preserving Harmony (Baohe dian) Built in 1420 in the early Ming dynasty, the hall has been destroyed in fire and rebuilt several times, but the extant main structure still dates back to the Ming dynasty.

translations.zh: 明初称谨身殿，明嘉靖四十一年（1562年）改称建极殿，清顺治二年（1645年）始称保和殿。
translations.en: It was named the Hall of Scrupulous Behaviour (Jinshen dian) in the early Ming dynasty, before being renamed the Hall of Establishing Supremacy (Jianji dian) in 1562.

translations.zh: “保和”出自《周易》，意即保持万物和谐。
translations.en: In 1645, the second year of the Shunzhi Emperor's reign at the beginning of the Qing dynasty, it received its present name.

translations.zh: 保和殿建筑面积1240平方米，建筑结构采用“减柱造”特殊法式，减去了殿内前檐6根柱子，开阔了空间。
translations.en: The phrase 'preserving harmony' is drawn from the Book of Changes (I Ching or Yi Jing) to refer to maintaining harmony among all things.

translations.zh: 灭火器箱殿内悬挂乾隆皇帝御笔“皇建有极”匾，意即人君建立天下最高准则火警6119
translations.en: The Hall of Preserving Harmony covers an area of 1,240 square metres, with six columns in the front of the hall omitted to widen the interior space.

translations.zh: 明代，大典前皇帝常在此更衣。
translations.en: The tablet hanging in the hall reads 'it is the emperor who establishes the highest principles' (huang jian you ji) in the Qianlong Emperor's hand.

translations.zh: 清代每年除夕、正月十五，皇帝在此宴请外藩、王公及一二品大臣。
translations.en: Ming dynasty emperors, before holding grand ceremonies, often changed their clothes in this hall, Qing dynasty emperors hosted banquets here, on the eve of the lunar new year and the fifteenth day of the first lunar month, for envoys, princes and high-ranking officials,

translations.zh: 清初，后三宫修复前，顺治帝、康熙帝曾在此居住，并相继易名为位育宫、清宁宫。
translations.en: Before the restoration of the three main palaces of the Inner Court in the early Qing dynasty, the Shunzhi and Kangxi emperors temporarily lived here, and the hall was successively renamed the Palace of Proper Cultivation (Weiyu gong) and the Palace of Pure Tranquility (Qingning gong).

translations.zh: 顺治皇帝大婚在此举行。
translations.en: The wedding ceremony of the Shunzhi Emperor was also held in this hall.

translations.zh: 清乾隆五十四年（1789年）这里成为“殿试”的固定场所
translations.en: In 1789, during the Qianlong Emperor's reign, this hall became the permanent site for the Palace Examinations.

translations.zh: 前言新疆和田玉是中华玉文化的主要载体。
translations.en: FOREWORD Hetian jade is the central pillar of Chinese jade culture.

translations.zh: 新疆地域辽阔，玉矿资源丰富。
translations.en: It comes from the vast and geologically complex terrain of Xinjiang,where archaeological evidence shows that jade has been used for over 4,000 years.

translations.zh: 考古证明新疆用玉的历史已超过4000年，若羌县楼兰古城出土的玉爷等工具是使用新疆玉料的最初阶段。
translations.en: Its earliest known use was in artifacts such as jade axes unearthed at the ancient Loulan site in Ruoqiang County, marking the initial phase of jade culture in the region.

translations.zh: 西汉中期以后，和田玉开始大量进入中原，并逐渐成为此后2000余年玉器制作的主要材料。
translations.en: After the mid-Western Han dynasty, jade from Hetian began flowing into central China.

translations.zh: 清乾隆二十六年（1761年）开始，和田玉每年春秋两季呈进宫廷，以贡玉制度的形式固定下来。
translations.en: It would dominate jade craftsmanship for the next 2,000 years.

translations.zh: 和田玉占据清代宫廷玉料的主要地位，其制作和使用空前发展和繁荣，中国玉器艺术进入历史上第三个发展高峰。
translations.en: From the 26th year of the Qianlong Emperor's reign (1761)onward, Hetian jade began entering the Qing court as yearly tributes in both spring and autumn, and became the main source of jade used in the imperial palace.

translations.zh: 故宫是中华五千多年文明的重要承载者、中华优秀传统文化的汇聚地和多元文化交流融合的历史见证。
translations.en: The production and use of Hetian jade wares made an unparalleled advance, sparking another development boom in Chinese jade culture.

translations.zh: 在故宫博物院百年华诞到来之际，本展览遴选具有代表性的清代宫廷和田玉精品，分为玉之源、玉之礼、玉之雅、玉之巧、玉之用五个单元，旨在诠释清代和田玉文化，展现清代各民族之间的交往交流交融，进一步铸牢中华民族共同体意识。
translations.en: The collections of the Palace Museum bear witness to over 5,000 years of Chinese civilization and stand as a testament to centuries of cultural exchange and integration.

translations.zh: 第一单元和田，位于新疆维吾尔自治区南部，古称“于阗”或“和阗”，意为“产玉的地方”，是中国历史上最重要的玉料产地。
translations.en: Hetian (和田), located in the south of Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, is historically known as Yutian (于阗) or Hetian (和阗), meaning a place that yields jade.

translations.zh: 和田玉是指主要由透闪石一阳起石矿物（Ca2（Mg，Fe)5[Si4O11]2（OH)2】组成、具有典型纤维交织结构、达到玉石级别的矿物集合体。
translations.en: It has long been the most significant source of jade in China.

translations.zh: 考古发掘证明，新疆闪石玉的开采可早自新石器时代，不过这一时期的玉制品还停留在简单工具等实用器上。
translations.en: Hetian jade is of the nephrite variety, primarily composed of tremolite and actinolite (Ca2(Mg,Fe)5[Si4O11]2(OH)2), with a distinctive interwoven fibrous structure that meets the quality required of gemstone.

translations.zh: 汉代以后，新疆和田玉料输入中原。
translations.en: Archaeological discoveries and historical records reveal that jade mining in Xinjiang dates to the Neolithic period, when tremolite jade was shaped mainly into simple tools.

translations.zh: 唐代，通过丝绸之路，玉石的运输更加快捷和便利。
translations.en: After the Han dynasty (206 BC-220 AD), Hetian jade began to be transported to central China.

translations.zh: 宋代以后，和田玉的开采和贸易持续不断，并逐渐成为中原用玉的重要来源。
translations.en: In the Tang dynasty (618-907), the Silk Road expedited the transportation of jade.

translations.zh: 明代开始，和田山料玉真正得以开采。
translations.en: As Hetian jade continued to be mined and traded through the Song dynasty (960-1279), it gradually established itself as the most important material for central Chinese jade craftsmanship.

translations.zh: 清乾隆二十四年（1759年）以后，和田良玉充贡宫廷，成为清代宫廷玉料的主要来源。
translations.en: By the Ming dynasty (1368-1644), miners were able to excavate Hetian jade deposits in mountains, and from 1759 onward, high-quality Hetian jade was regularly presented to the Qing court as tribute, and this became the primary source for imperial jade.

translations.zh: 第四单元清宫赏玩用玉是供品鉴、摩挲、娱乐的玉器，如各式玉料上佳、雕工精巧的和田玉摆件，收纳于盒、屉、匣、函中的小件玉器，以及围棋、象棋、双陆等消遣品。
translations.en: Section 4 Ingeniously-crafted Jade Jade artifacts crafted for enjoyment of the Qing court were designed for appreciation, tactile pleasure, and leisure.

translations.zh: 乾隆皇帝在政务之余，与玉为伍，真实触及山川精华，体验天人合一，达到赏玩玉器的最高境界。
translations.en: They included finely carved Hetian jade ornaments, small jade items kept in boxes and cases, and recreational items like Go boards, chess pieces, backgammon, and other game sets.

translations.zh: 清朝乾隆、嘉庆年间，一批中亚、南亚、西亚至东欧地区制作的玉器传入宫廷。
translations.en: During the Qianlong and Jiaqing reigns, jade pieces from Central, South, and West Asia, as well as Eastern Europe, found their way into the imperial court via Xinjiang.

translations.zh: 乾隆皇帝将其命名为痕都斯坦玉器，学术界称之为伊斯兰玉器。
translations.en: These imported jades were named by the Qianlong Emperor as Hindustan jades', and known today as 'Islamic jades' in the academic world.

translations.zh: 以玉为媒介的交往，反映了清朝与域外地区的艺术交流，彰显出中华文明的开放与包容。
translations.en: This artistic exchange through jade reflects the cultural interaction between China and the world, highlighting the openness and inclusiveness of Chinese civilization,

translations.zh: 第五单元清代宫廷对和田玉的日常使用以佩饰和器皿为大宗。
translations.en: Section 5 Jade Ornaments and Dining Wares In the Qing court, Hetian jade adorned everyday life, being crafted into ornaments and vessels for daily use.

translations.zh: 以玉为饰，源于对美的追求。
translations.en: This tradition of jade adornment embodies the pursuit of beauty.

translations.zh: 儒家将君子应具备的仁、义、礼、智、信等美好品德与玉的自然属性相比附，玉被赋予五德或十一德，“君子比德于玉”“君子无故玉不去身”的思想深入人心。
translations.en: The Confucian ideal likens the qualities of a gentleman—benevolence, righteousness, propriety, wisdom, and faithfulness—to jade's natural attributes, with jade symbolizing between five and eleven virtues.

translations.zh: 清代玉质饮食器主要包括碗、盘、壶、杯、箸、匙等，既有精雕细琢者，亦有成批量制作的光素盘、碗等。
translations.en: The Qing court's jade dining vessels included bowls, plates, teapots, cups, chopsticks, and spoons, with some exquisitely carved and others produced in simpler, undecorated forms.

translations.zh: 和田玉饮食器的小规模制作始于乾隆十八年（1753年），大规模制作在乾隆四十年（1775年）以后，于乾隆皇帝七十寿诞（1780年）达到鼎盛。
translations.en: Small-scale production of Hetian jade diningware began in the eighteenth year of the Qianlong reign (1753), with larger-scale production beginning after the fortieth year (1775), peaking around the emperor's seventieth birthday in 1780

translations.zh: 结语新疆和田，东方美玉的主要产地，新疆和田玉，中华玉文化的主要载体。
translations.en: EPILOGUE Hetian, the major source of jade throughout East Asia.

translations.zh: 当珍贵的玉石与深厚的文化相关联，是否感受到细腻与坚韧、内敛与舒张、温润与博大，可曾唤起对崇山、沙漠、戈壁、河流的美妙联想。
translations.en: Hetian jade, the central pillar of Chinese jade culture.

translations.zh: 它们，既是礼制的缩影，承载庄重与威严，也是生活的折射，体现人文与习俗；更是各民族交往交流交融的表现，见证辉煌与认同。
translations.en: When precious stone intertwines with profound heritage, One feels its refinement and resilience, its grace and vigor, its warmth and boundless depth Does it not awaken visions of towering mountains, vast deserts, windswept plains, and rivers?

translations.zh: 玉之德，亦为君子之德言念君子，温其如玉。
translations.en: These jades, as symbols of ritual, carry solemnity and dignity.

translations.zh: 第三单元清代宫廷玉器注重风雅和意趣，尤以文房清供与仿古制作为最，多以品质优良的和田琢制而成。
translations.en: Section 3 Elegance of Jade Imperial jade ware of the Qing dynasty exudes elegance and refinement, as is particularly admired in accoutrements of the scholar's study and in Hetian jade.

translations.zh: 玉质文房用具造型异彩纷呈，雄浑古朴、清新雅致、繁华美兼而有之，装饰纹样亦充满文人闲雅之趣，兼具实用性和观赏性。
translations.en: Jade stationery varies in style, ranging from the robust and primitive to the creative and delicate, and from the intricately adorned to the beautifully restrained, often featuring decorative motifs conveying a sense of literati grace.

translations.zh: 乾隆时期，文人雅士追古、嗜古之风气盛。
translations.en: These pieces were both functional and visually appealing.

translations.zh: 乾隆皇帝大量制作仿古玉器，既是对文人尚古、慕古思想的认同，也是其追求古朴风雅之美和“进德”“精艺”“与古人相见”之境界的体现。
translations.en: During the Qianlong reign, reverence and admiration for antiquity took still deeper root among the literati than in past dynasties.

translations.zh: 位于今江西省万年县的仙人洞遗址曾出土过距今约两万年的陶片，该遗址与位于广西壮族自治区桂林市的甄皮岩遗址、浙江省浦江县的上山遗址等新石器时代早期遗址，还曾出土过距今约一万年的陶器。
translations.en: Pottery fragments from about 20,000 years ago were found in an archaeological site called Xianrendong in Jiangxi Province.

translations.zh: 在陕西省华县老官台、浙江省余姚市河姆渡、杭州市萧山区跨湖桥、河北省武安县磁山、河南省新郑县裴李岗、甘肃省秦安县大地湾等新石器时代中期遗址，均出土过距今约7000～8000年的陶器。
translations.en: In early Neolithic sites such as the above-mentioned one in Jiangxi Province, and others in Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region and Zhejiang Province, pottery dating back roughly 10,000 years has also been excavated.

translations.zh: 这些陶器的烧成温度约为600～700℃，颜色有红褐、灰黑等，带有一定的原始性，是研究早期陶器的重要实物资料。
translations.en: Meanwhile, pottery from the middle Neolithic era excavated from the sites in Shaanxi, Zhejiang, Hebei, Henan, and Gansu provinces was baked at 600-700°C and red or grey-black in colour.

translations.zh: 北京容城安新天津天清河保定。
translations.en: These articles are important for the study of early pottery.

translations.zh: 河海阳正定石家庄卫新河10厘米10厘米5厘米10厘米邢台。
translations.en: It.

translations.zh: 交泰殿原名中圆殿，明嘉靖十四年（1535年）更名交泰殿，殿名出自《周易》“乾坤交泰”，意为天地相交，阴阳协和。
translations.en: Hall of Union [Jiaotaidian] Originally named the Hall of Middle Perfection (Zhongyuan dian), the Hall of Union (Jiaotai dian) got its present name in 1535, the fourteenth year of the Jiajing Emperor's reign in the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644).

translations.zh: 清嘉庆二年（1797年）因乾清宫失火及此处而重建。
translations.en: The current name comes from the Book of Changes (l Ching or Yi Jing) and refers to the union of heaven and earth and harmony between yin and yang.

translations.zh: 殿平面呈方形，上置铜鎏金宝顶，形式与中和殿略同。
translations.en: It was rebuilt in 1797, the second year of the Jiaqing reign in the Qing Dynasty (1644-1911), after being damaged by a fire which started at the adjacent Palace of Heavenly Purity (Qianqing gong).

translations.zh: 殿内正中设宝座，宝座后上方悬挂乾隆皇帝摹康熙皇帝御笔“无为”匾，下设乾隆御制《交泰殿铭》屏风。
translations.en: With a square floor plan, the Hall of Union features a gold-plated bronze finial (baoding) on the roof, of similar design to that of the Hall of Middle Harmony (Zhonghe dian).

translations.zh: 东侧为中国古代计时器铜壶滴漏，西侧为大自鸣钟。
translations.en: A throne occupies the centre of the hall.

translations.zh: 清代皇后在千秋（皇后生日）、元旦（春节）、冬至三大节于此接受朝贺。
translations.en: Behind it hangs a tablet inscribed with 'non-action' (wu wei, a key Daoist concept), in calligraphy by the Qianlong Emperor in imitation of the Kangxi Emperor's handwriting.

translations.zh: 乾隆十三年（1748年），乾隆皇帝将二十五方宝玺存放于此。
translations.en: Directly beneath the tablet is a screen bearing the Ode to the Hall of Union, composed by the Qianlong Emperor.

translations.zh: 铜缸、铁缸铜缸、铁缸是宫中的防火设备之一，平时贮满清水，以备灭火时用。
translations.en: Bronze and Iron Vats Usually filled with water, these bronze and iron vats were used to protect the imperial palace from fire.

translations.zh: 每到冬季小雪节气至翌年惊蛰，在缸外套上棉套，缸上加盖，气温低时，缸下烧炭加温，以防缸水冻结。
translations.en: Between Xiaoxue (Light Snow) and Jingzhe (Awakening of Insects) in solar terms, the vats were wrapped in cotton cloth to prevent the water from freezing.

translations.zh: 紫禁城内现存最早的缸为明弘治年间铸造。
translations.en: The earliest vat now preserved in the Forbidden City was cast during the Hongzhi reign (1488-1505) in the Ming Dynasty (1368-1644).

translations.zh: 明代的缸两耳均加素面铁环，样式上奢下敛，古朴大方。
translations.en: Ming vats are simple yet elegant, with plain iron rings on the sides and a wider upper body with a tapered base.

translations.zh: 清代的缸两耳多加兽面环，腹大口收。
translations.en: Qing Dynasty (1644-1911) vats feature rings held by side knobs with the faces of beasts, a large belly and a smaller mouth.

translations.zh: 宫中现设大小铜、铁、鎏金铜缸共二百余口，其中鎏金铜缸22口，分别陈设在太和殿、保和殿、乾清门和乾清宫两边。
translations.en: At present there are over 200 bronze and iron vats in the Palace Museum, including twenty-two gilt bronze ones flanking the Hall of Supreme Harmony (Taihe dian), the Hall of Preserving Harmony (Baohe dian), the Gate of Heavenly Purity (Qianqing men) and the Palace of Heavenly Purity (Qianqing gong).

translations.zh: 爱护文物、古建请勿攀爬、刻画
translations.en: Please take care of the cultural heritage. No Climbing or Graffiti

translations.zh: 养心殿明代嘉靖年间建造，位于乾清宫西侧。
translations.en: Hall of Mental Cultivation (Yangxin dian) Constructed during the Jiajing reign (1522-1566) in the Ming dynasty, this hall stands west of the Palace of Heavenly Purity (Qianqing gong).

translations.zh: 清代康熙年间，这里作为内廷造办处，专门制作宫廷御用物品。
translations.en: During the Kangxi Emperor's reign (1662-1722) in the Qing dynasty, it housed the Imperial Workshops, producing exclusive artifacts for court use.

translations.zh: 自雍正皇帝移居养心殿后，造办处的各作坊遂逐渐迁出，这里就一直作为皇帝的寝宫。
translations.en: After the subsequent Yongzheng Emperor moved into the hall, these workshops were gradually phased out, and the hall became the emperor's principal residence.

translations.zh: 乾隆年间完成大幅改造、添建，成为一组集皇帝召见群臣、处理政务和生活起居为一体的多功能建筑群。
translations.en: A major renovation during the Qianlong reign (1736-1795) expanded it into an integrated complex in which emperors lived, met officials, and carried out administrative tasks.

translations.zh: 直到溥仪出宫，清代有八位皇帝先后居住在养心殿。
translations.en: Eight successive Qing emperors resided here until Puyi's expulsion in 1924.

translations.zh: 养心殿西梢间为“三希堂”。
translations.en: The westernmost chamber houses the Hall of Three Rarities (Sanxi tang), while the eastern chamber features dual thrones separated by a yellow silk partition, the iconic setting for the joint regency of the Empress Dowagers Cixi and Ci'an in the late Qing.

translations.zh: 坤宁宫明代皇后寝宫。
translations.en: Palace of Earthly Tranquility [Kunninggong] The Palace of Earthly Tranquility served as the residence of the empress in the Ming Dynasty.

translations.zh: 坤宁宫与前面的乾清宫分别为传统意义上的帝、后寝宫，“乾清”“坤宁”寓意天清地宁即天高明、地博厚。
translations.en: In traditional thought it formed a pair with the Palace of Heavenly Purity (Qianqing gong), the residence of the emperor, with heaven characterized by lofty wisdom while the earth represented by rich breadth and lenience.

translations.zh: 坤宁宫建于明永乐十八年（1420年）。
translations.en: The Palace of Earthly Tranquility was built in the early Ming Dynasty in 1420.

translations.zh: 现在的坤宁宫为清顺治十二年（1655年）仿盛京（沈阳）清宁宫改建后的样式，门不居中而偏东侧，成为有满族特色的“口袋房”。
translations.en: The structure we see today was rebuilt in 1655 in the Qing Dynasty, in imitation of the Palace of Pure Tranquility (Qingning gong) in Shengjing (present-day Shenyang). The entrance is located on the east end of the building's facade, rather than in the middle, giving the palace a pocket house' style with distinctive Manchu features.

translations.zh: 清康熙时将东侧两间用作皇帝大婚的洞房，年幼登基的康熙、同治、光绪三帝以及逊帝薄仪均在此大婚。
translations.en: During the Kangxi Emperor's reign, the two bays on the east end were used as the emperor's bridal chamber. Qing Dynasty Emperors Kangxi, Tongzhi, Guangxu, and the last emperor Puyi, all of whom ascended the throne at a young age, completed their wedding here.

translations.zh: 西侧五间为萨满教祭祀神堂，内设安放神像、宝座的环形大炕和制作祭品的煮肉大锅等。
translations.en: The five bays on the west side were used as a shrine for shamanistic sacrifices, housing a U-shaped kang bed-stove on which the idols and a throne were placed, and cauldrons for cooking sacrificial meat.

source.title_zh: 钦安殿
source.title_en: Hall of Imperial Peace [Qin'an dian]

translations.zh: 钦安殿始建于明代，嘉靖十四年（1535年）添建墙垣后自成格局。
translations.en: First constructed in the Ming Dynasty(1368-1644), this hall developed into an independent yard after the surrounding walls were built during the Jiajing reign in 1535.

source.title_zh: 钦安殿
source.title_en: Hall of Imperial Peace [Qin'an dian]

translations.zh: 殿为黄琉璃瓦重檐盔顶，坐落在汉白玉单层须弥座上，面阔5间，进深3间。
translations.en: Standing on a single-tier Xumizuo base of carved white marble, the five-bay-long and three-bay-wide hall features a flat-topped roof with double eaves and yellow-glazed tiles.

source.title_zh: 钦安殿
source.title_en: Hall of Imperial Peace [Qin'an dian]

translations.zh: 殿内供奉玄天上帝。
translations.en: Inside the hall is a statue of the Supreme Lord of the Numinous Heaven (Xuantian Shangdi).

source.title_zh: 钦安殿
source.title_en: Hall of Imperial Peace [Qin'an dian]

translations.zh: 清朝每年元旦于天一门内设斗坛，皇帝在此括香行礼。
translations.en: Every New Year's Day, the Qing court set up an altar behind the Gate of Heaven's Primacy (Tianyi men), the south gate of the complex, where the emperor would burn joss sticks and pay homage.

source.title_zh: 钦安殿
source.title_en: Hall of Imperial Peace [Qin'an dian]

translations.zh: 每遇年节，钦安殿设道场，道场事务由太监道士管理。
translations.en: On festive occasions Taoist rites would be performed in this hall, overseen by eunuch Taoist priests.

source.title_zh: 钦安殿
source.title_en: Hall of Imperial Peace [Qin'an dian]

translations.zh: 道光十九年（1839年）起，下旨停设道场。
translations.en: This tradition lasted until the Daoguang Emperor abolished it in 1839.

translations.zh: 三希堂原名温室，清乾隆十一年（1746年）改造并更名为三希堂，是乾隆皇帝读书之处。
translations.en: Hall of Three Rarities (Sanxitang) Originally named the Warm Chamber (Wenshi), this space was renovated and renamed the Hall of Three Rarities in the 11th year of the Qianlong Emperor's reign (1746).

translations.zh: 堂名“三希”有两重含义：一是，乾隆皇帝将所藏晋代大书法家王羲之的《快雪时晴帖》、王献之的《中秋帖》和王珣的《伯远帖》三件稀世之宝，珍藏于此。
translations.en: The name 'Three Rarities' holds dual significance. First, it refers to three priceless calligraphy masterpieces by renowned Jin dynasty (265-420) calligraphers, including Timely Clearing After Snowfall by Wang Xizhi (303-361), Mid-Autumn Manuscript by Wang Xianzhi (344-386), and Letter to Boyuan by Wang Xun (350-401), which the Qianlong Emperor treasured and stored here.

translations.zh: 二是寄托了乾隆皇帝“士希贤，贤希圣，圣希天”的精神追求。
translations.en: Second, it embodies the Emperor's phrasing of three aspirations: 'Scholars aspire to become virtuous, the virtuous aspire to become sages, and sages aspire to follow the Way of Heaven'.

translations.zh: 乾隆皇帝书写的“三希堂”匾和对联“怀抱观古今，深心托豪素”至今还挂在室内东墙上。
translations.en: To this day, the 'Hall of Three Rarities' plaque in the Emperor's own hand, along with a matching couplet, 'Embracing Past and Present in Contemplation, Entrusting Profound Thoughts to the Brush', remain displayed on the eastern wall.

translations.zh: 神武门紫禁城北门，建成于明永乐十八年（1420年），时称“玄武门”，清康熙年间重建时，为避康熙皇帝玄烨名讳而改称“神武门”。
translations.en: Gate of Divine Prowess (Shenwu men) The northern gate of the Forbidden City, the Gate of Divine Prowess (Shenwu men) was built in the Ming Dynasty in 1420, the eighteenth year of the Yongle Emperor's reign, and was initially called the Gate of Xuanwu after the ancient Chinese deity of the North.

translations.zh: 神武门作为皇宫的后门，是宫内日常出入的重要门禁。
translations.en: When it was rebuilt in the Qing Dynasty during the Kangxi Emperor's reign (1662-1722), it was renamed to avoid using the character Xuan, which was taboo as it was part of the Emperor's birth name Aisin Gioro Xuanye.

translations.zh: 明清皇后祭祀先蚕坛时，由神武门正门出入。
translations.en: As the rear gate of the imperial palace, the Gate of Divine Prowess played an important role in daily access.

translations.zh: 清代选秀女时，待选的秀女由神武门偏门进出。
translations.en: During the Ming and Qing dynasties, the empress would exit and enter through the main passage of this gate when going to the Altar to the Silkworm Goddess (Xiancan tan) to offer sacrifices.

translations.zh: 故宫博物院观众服务热线400-950-1925
translations.en: In the Qing Dynasty, young girls chosen as candidates for the imperial harem would enter the Forbidden City via the side passages of this gate.

translations.zh: 史前约70万年前一公元前21世纪早在旧石器时代，，“北京人”在房山周口店一带生活，开启了北京地区70多万年的人居史。
translations.en: DAWN OF CIVILIZATION Ca.700,000 YEARS AGO-21st CENTURY BCE district of modern Beijing, marking the beginning of human settlement in the Beijing area.

translations.zh: 进入新石器时代，磨制石器和陶器出现，原始农业产生并日益发展，迎来了文明的初曙；在此期间，北京发挥着周边文化南下北上的纽带作用，形成了北京最初的多元文化融汇局面，奠定了北京在早期中国文化圈形成和发展过程中的重要地位。
translations.en: During the Neolithic period, traces of human activities in Beijing area can be identified from the unearthed objects, such as polished stone tools, pottery and seeds of primitive agriculture

translations.zh: 史前约70万年前一公元前21世纪早在旧石器时代，，“北京人”在房山周口店一带生活，开启了北京地区70多万年的人居史。
translations.en: DAWN OF CIVILIZATION Ca.700000YEARSAGO-21ST CENTURY BCE More than 700,000 years ago, the Peking Man inhabited at Zhoukoudian in Fangshan district of modern Beijing, marking the beginning of human settlement in the Beijing area.

translations.zh: 进入新石器时代，磨制石器和陶器出现，原始农业产生并日益发展，迎来了文明的初曙；在此期间，北京发挥着周边文化南下北上的纽带作用，形成了北京最初的多元文化融汇局面，奠定了北京在早期中国文化圈形成和发展过程中的重要地位。
translations.en: During the Neolithic period, traces of human activities in Beijing area can be identified from the unearthed objects, such as polished stone tools,pottery and seeds of primitive agriculture.

translations.zh: 旧石器时代北京地区是远古人类活动较早的地区之一。
translations.en: PALEOLITHIC PERIOD The Peking Man, New Cave Man, Tianyuan Cave Man and Upper Cave Man in the Paleolithic period successively inhabited at Zhoukoudian, southwest of Beijing city. They represent the process of evolution from Homo erectus and early Homo sapiens to modern humans.

translations.zh: 在旧石器时代，以北京周口店遗址为典型代表，发现有“北京人”“新洞人”田园洞人”和“山顶洞人”，代表了古人类从直立人、古老型智人到早期现代人的不同发展阶段。
translations.en: This ancient cultural stage of human development characterized by the use of chipped stone tools.

translations.zh: 新石器时代距今一万年左右，东胡林人最早驯化了粟（小米），引发了从采集到旱作农耕生产方式的革命性变化。
translations.en: NEOLITHIC PERIOD About 10,000 years ago, the Donghulin Man in the Beijing area, was among the earliest to domesticate the foxtail millet, which caused a

translations.zh: 距今八千年始，北京沟通南北的纽带作用凸显，成为中原、北方、海岱地区不同文化碰撞交流的前沿，其文化所呈现出交融汇聚的特点从未间断。
translations.en: years ago, Beijing served as the cultural nexus, influenced by the surrounded cultures.

translations.zh: 距今五千年左右，以雪山二期文化为代表，北京地区初现文明曙光。
translations.en: About 5,000 years ago, the Phase ll of Xueshan Culture shed light on the early signs of civilization.

translations.zh: 《山海经》中称夏代的北京及东北一带为“玄丘”。
translations.en: PEOPLE INHABITED IN THE ANCIENT YAN AREA

translations.zh: 这时的北京地区是中原、北方、海岱三大文化区的交汇地带，中原腹地的二里头文化藉由北京地区影响到北方的夏家店下层文化。
translations.en: In the Xia dynasty, the culture of this region was influenced by the Erlitou Culture of the Central Plains of northern China and cast its influence on the lower Xiajiadian Culture in the northern area.

translations.zh: 直至商代晚期，北京地区发展成殷商王朝北部的方国。
translations.en: Up to the late Shang dynasty, the state emerged in the Beijing region.

translations.zh: 夏商周公元前21世纪一前222年夏商时期的北京作为连接北方、东北与中原地区的咽喉要地，区域内文化融合并汇的局面继续发展。
translations.en: EARLY STAGE OF BEIJING CITY XIA, SHANG AND ZHOU DYNASTIES (21st CENTURY BCE-222 BCE) Beijing was located at the core of areas including North, Northeast and Central Plains, which enhanced cultural integration and convergence under the Xia and Shang dynasties.

translations.zh: 周初于北京地区分封燕、蓟等诸侯国，燕、蓟的都城不仅是北京地区建城史的开端，也是中原礼制文化向北方和东北地区传播的前驱。
translations.en: At the beginning of the Zhou dynasty, the subordinate states of Yan and Ji built their cities in the Beijing proper, which marked the beginning of the city construction in history.

translations.zh: 至战国时期，燕国地跨燕山南北，为战国七雄。
translations.en: By the Warring States period, Yan became one of the seven major states.

translations.zh: 周代实行分封制，封邦建国，以拱卫周王室。
translations.en: FEUDAL STATES:YANANDJI

translations.zh: 周武王克商后，褒封先圣之后于蓟，封其弟召公（奭）于燕。
translations.en: Under the early Western Zhou, there were two feudal states of Ji and Yan in Beijing area served as strong bastions to the north.

translations.zh: 燕、蓟遵循周朝的礼制文化，是周朝北部的坚强屏障。
translations.en: The Zhou king appointed a descendant of the Yellow (or Yao)Emperor to rule Ji, and the Duke of Shao, a very important figure to rule Yan.

translations.zh: 燕国于西周晚期吞并了蓟国，至战国时期拓土开疆，发展成“地广两千里”的大国，是“战国七雄”之一。
translations.en: During the late Western Zhou period, the State of Yan annexed the neighboring State of Ji.

translations.zh: 其疆域内不同的文化在融合中继续发展。
translations.en: By the Warring States period, the Yan became one of the seven major states

translations.zh: 秦代北京地区分属上谷、渔阳、右北平、广阳四郡。
translations.en: MIXED SYSTEM OF GOVERNMENT Under the Qin dynasty, this Beijing area was divided into four prefectures, began to directly subordinate to the central government.

translations.zh: 两汉时实行郡国并行，北京地区设有燕国（广阳国），蓟城四度成为诸侯国都城，四度为郡治首府。
translations.en: In the time of the Han dynasty, both prefectures and subordinate kingdoms existed. The city of Ji (Beijing) continued to be the seat of administration of the subordinate kingdoms and prefectures.

translations.zh: 作为中原王朝控扼北方的要地，北京的军事重镇地位不断上升。
translations.en: Beijing area was a bastion for the imperial court to take control of the northern regions

translations.zh: 秦汉至隋唐五代公元前221一公元960年秦统一全国后，推行郡县制，广修驰道、直道。
translations.en: A KEY GARRISON TOWN IN THE NORTH FROM THE QIN AND HAN DYNASTIES TO THE SUI TANG AND FIVE DYNASTIES PERIOD(221BCE-960 CE)

translations.zh: 北京处在居庸关大道、太行山东麓大道、燕山南麓大道和古北口大道的交汇点上，所设郡县跨越燕山南北，农耕文明与游牧、渔猎文明的交往愈加频繁。
translations.en: The Qin Emperor constructed a network of roads to improve communications within his united Empire.

translations.zh: 北京地区凭借地理区位优势，成为北方军事重镇和推动中华民族共同体形成的民族交往融合的中心。
translations.en: Beijing lay at the junction of several these roads.

translations.zh: 魏晋南北朝时期的北京地区，各族竞汇，政局动荡频仍，其军事重镇地位愈加凸显。
translations.en: ADMINISTRATION UNDER THE PREFECTURE GOVERNORS The status of the region as a military stronghold became more prominent.

translations.zh: 幽州刺史作为地方军政长官，在乌桓、鲜卑等各种力量中纵横捭阖。
translations.en: The renowned Chinese warlord Cao Cao campaigned against the Wuhuan in the northeastern China taking Ji as a base.

translations.zh: 曹操以蓟城为据点，伐辽东三郡乌桓；西晋末年幽州刺史王浚与鲜卑段部联姻以巩固自己的势力；十六国时期，鲜卑慕容部建立的前燕政权还曾一度以蓟城为都；拓跋鲜卑建立的北魏政权据有幽州后，以蓟城为据点伐北燕，最终实现北方的统一。
translations.en: During the late Western Jin period, the Governor of Youzhou Prefecture, Wang Jun,formed an alliance with the Xianbei Duan clan through marriage to consolidate his own power.

translations.zh: 隋唐时期，全国统一，大运河通达北京，北京地区军事重镇的地位进一步加强。
translations.en: ADMINISTRATION UNDER THE REGIONAL MILITARY GOVERNOR Under the Emperor Xuanzong of the Tang, a large number of troops were stationed in Youzhou (Beijing), under the administration of a military governor, to defend against rising threats from the northern neighbours.

translations.zh: 唐玄宗开元天宝之际，为防御日益强大起来的契丹和奚，幽州节度使威权日盛。
translations.en: In 755, An Lushan, a powerful military governor, launched a great rebellion that made Beijing area plunged into turmoil.

translations.zh: 隋唐时期，全国统一，大运河通达北京，北京地区军事重镇的地位进一步加强。
translations.en: ADMINISTRATION UNDER THE REGIONAL MILITARY GOVERNOR Under the Emperor Xuanzong of the Tang, a large number of troops were stationed in Youzhou (Beijing), under the administration of a military governor, to defend against rising threats from the northern neighbours.

translations.zh: 唐玄宗开元天宝之际，为防御日益强大起来的契丹和奚，幽州节度使威权日盛。
translations.en: In 755, An Lushan, a powerful military governor, launched a great rebellion that made Beijing area plunge into turmoil.

translations.zh: 汉唐间的北京，因其特有的地理区位成为民族融合的舞台。
translations.en: MULTICULTURAL INTEGRATION From the Han Dynasty to the Tang Dynasty, Beijing remained home to multiple ethnic groups and held an open attitude towards foreign cultures.

translations.zh: 秦汉统一局面的出现，促进了域内民族间的交往；汉唐时雄浑开放的胸襟，也在不断吸纳域外文化。
translations.en: Especially in the period of the Wei, Jin, Southern and Northern dynasties, Beijing fostered extensive ethnic integration and exchanges between diverse ethnic cultures.

translations.zh: 辽金两代的社会风俗，如信仰、婚俗、服饰等，对后世产生了重要影响，故元人有言“万里河山有燕赵，百年风气尚辽金”。
translations.en: ETHNIC INTEGRATION The social customs of the Liao and Jin dynasties, such as religious beliefs, wedding traditions and dressing style, greatly influenced later dynasties.

translations.zh: 辽金时期的北京，民族交流和文化融合频繁，中华民族多元一体的格局进一步深化。
translations.en: With more frequent ethnic exchanges and cultural integration, Beijing further contributed to the pluralistic unity of the Chinese nation

translations.zh: 公元916—1234年从公元九世纪开始，我国东北地区古老的民族契丹和女真相继崛起。
translations.en: EARLY STAGE OF THE CAPITAL CITY LIAO AND JIN DYNASTIES (916-1234) Since the 9th century, the Khitans and Jurchens in the northeastern region of China successively rose to power.

translations.zh: 契丹人建立了辽（916-1125年），女真人建立了金（1115-1234年）。
translations.en: The Liao and Jin dynasties established by these people made the city of Beijing their secondary capital and main capital successively.

translations.zh: 辽升幽州为南京，金则于此建中都，北京由陪都递升演进为一代王朝的都城，政治、军事地位进一步提升，为后来元明清时期大一统王朝定都北京奠定了基础。
translations.en: This not only further solidified its status as a political, economic and military center, but also laid the foundations for subsequent wholly unified states to take it as the capital.

translations.zh: 辽天显十三年（938年），辽太宗耶律德光升幽州为南京。
translations.en: In 938, the Liao Emperor made the city of Youzhou (Beijing) his southern capital (Nanjing).

translations.zh: 北京辽南京与上京、东京、中京、西京并称辽五京，开始以都城的面目出现在历史舞台，城市性质发生了质的转变。
translations.en: Nanjing became one of the secondary capitals, since then the city began to take on the role of a capital city.

translations.zh: 辽南京在辽五京中最为富强，有“兵戎冠天下之雄，与赋当域中之半”之誉。
translations.en: Although the Liao had five capitals (principal, southern, eastern, western and central), Nanjing was the largest and in many ways the most important.

translations.zh: 十二世纪初，生活于我国东北松花江流域的女真人日渐强盛。
translations.en: JIN ZHONGDU: THE MAIN CAPITAL In the early 12th century, the Jurchens inhabiting in the northeastern part of China, rose to power.

translations.zh: 公元1115年，女真首领完颜阿骨打正式建国称帝，国号“金”。
translations.en: In 1115, the Jurchen leader Wanyan Aguda proclaimed himself emperor of the Jin dynasty.

translations.zh: 1153年，金朝第四个皇帝（贬号海陵王）完颜亮将首都从上京（黑龙江阿城）迁移至燕京（今北京），并模仿宋汴梁改建辽南京，称“中都”。
translations.en: In 1153, the fourth Jin emperor used the city of Nanjing (Beijing) as the main capital under the name of 'Zhongdu'.

translations.zh: 北京成为一代王朝的正式首都。
translations.en: Beijing became, for the first time, the main capital of a large empire which included most of north China.

translations.zh: 元代疆土广袤，域内民族众多，还有很多从中亚、西亚迁徙而来的色目人，“四方之民，风俗不一”。
translations.en: MULTI-ETHNIC COMMUNITY From Khubilai Khan time on China proper was reunited with Mongolia, Manchuria, and Tibet all in together.

translations.zh: 大都是元朝的政治中心，也是多民族杂处融合、多元文化交流融汇的中心，在中华民族多元一体格局形成的关键阶段发挥了重要作用，也是中华文明包容性的体现。
translations.en: Multi-ethnic groups lived in the same empire.

translations.zh: 元人赞叹北京的山川形胜称：幽燕之地，龙蟠虎踞，形势雄伟，南控江淮，北连朔漠”。
translations.en: People of the Yuan dynasty admired the landscape of Beijing, describing it as "Beijing is strategically located as an important city bridging the steppe in the north and the China Plain in the south."

translations.zh: 至元四年（1267年），忽必烈定都于燕，开始大规模兴建新都。
translations.en: In 1267, Kublai Khan moved his capital to Beijing and initiated the construction of a new capital city in a large scale.

translations.zh: 元人黄文仲的《大都赋》描绘了大都的壮丽，最后总结说：“惟其有大元之大，故能成大都之雄”
translations.en: The poet Huang Wenzhong depicted Dadu in his Ode to Dadu, that "For the sake of the powerful Yuan empire that Dadu could have the chance to be like this."

translations.zh: 元代的中国空前统一，在开放包容的格局下，在航海技术进步、京杭大运河的贯通等因素影响下，大都城“四方异域之人会聚”，日益富庶繁华，其繁华恰如元诗所描绘“京师天下本，万国赴如水。
translations.en: A BUSTLING METROPOLIS The Mongol conquests expanded contacts across Eurasia,which led to the transfer of technical and scientific knowledge.

translations.zh: 珠犀从南来，狗马由西止”。
translations.en: The spread of maritime technology and the unhindered operation of the Grand Canal contributed to north-south trade and the prosperity of Dadu.

translations.zh: 都城之内，除了皇族和官僚以外，还居住着数量庞大的平民。
translations.en: Dadu became one of the greatest metropolises in the world, home to many different communities.

translations.zh: 这些普通人家的生活日常，不外柴米油盐、吃穿住行，然其中亦自有大都的风情和气象。
translations.en: Daily lives of the natives other than aristocracies and officials also showed the unique style of Dadu

translations.zh: 公元1368-1644年明初，成祖朱由南京迁都北京，北京的都城文化承接前代而继续发展。
translations.en: EXEMPLARY REPRESENTATIVE OF DYNASTIC CAPITAL CITIES MING DYNASTY (1368-1644) In the early Ming dynasty, Emperor Zhu Di, moved the imperial capital from Nanjing to Beijing, which led to the future development of the city of Beijing.

translations.zh: 明代北京城是在元大都的基础上改建、增建而成，都城中轴线的继承、发展与完善是其突出的成就之一，北京作为古代都城规划、建设的典范之作至此基本形成。
translations.en: On its expansion from Dadu, one of its remarkable accomplishments was the legacy of the central axis of the city.

translations.zh: 城市性质的转变还带来了城市人口数量和阶层的相应改变，来自全国各地的物产、人才等荟萃于此，推动了北京城市商业、手工业、文化教育、宗教与民族融合等诸方面的繁荣兴盛。
translations.en: As the capital city, changes in the size and social structure of its population also occurred, fostering prosperity in commerce, handicraft industry, culture, education, religion and ethnic integration as a hub for goods and talents from across the country.

translations.zh: 洪武元年（1368年），明朝定都应天（今南京），改大都为北平。
translations.en: TRANSFER OF THE CAPITAL TO BEIJING In 1368, the Ming dynasty established its capital in present-day Nanjing.

translations.zh: 建文元年（1399年）燕王朱起兵“靖难”，最终夺得帝位，建元永乐，是为明成祖。
translations.en: In 1399, Emperor Zhu Di, usurped the throne.

translations.zh: 永乐元年（1403年），明成祖改北平为北京，永乐十八年下诏以北京为京师，正式迁都北京。
translations.en: Zhu Di's granted land was in the northeast of Ming territory, thus he had experience to fight against the Mongols.

translations.zh: 建都北京及修筑长城、完善九镇等共同构建了明代军事布防中的“天子守边”格局。
translations.en: In 1420, he moved the main residence of the court and seat of the military power.

translations.zh: 公元1271-1368年金代末期，蒙古族崛起，先后亡夏、灭金、克宋，建立起大一统王朝。
